# TypeScript Skill

> Type-safe JavaScript development for {{category}} projects

## When to Use

Use this skill when working with TypeScript files, type definitions, or strict type checking.

## Key Concepts

| Concept | Description | Use Case |
|---------|-------------|----------|
| Strict Mode | Enables all strict type checks | Catch errors at compile time |
| Generics | Reusable typed components | Collections, API responses |
| Type Guards | Runtime type narrowing | Safe type assertions |
| Utility Types | Built-in type transformations | Partial, Pick, Omit, etc. |

## Patterns for {{category}}

```typescript
// Type-safe API response
interface ApiResponse<T> {
  data: T;
  error?: string;
}

// Discriminated union for states
type State =
  | { status: 'loading' }
  | { status: 'success'; data: Data }
  | { status: 'error'; error: Error };

// Type guard
function isSuccess(state: State): state is { status: 'success'; data: Data } {
  return state.status === 'success';
}
```

## Pitfalls

- Avoid `any` - use `unknown` for truly unknown types
- Don't ignore type errors with `// @ts-ignore`
- Prefer interfaces for objects, types for unions
- Use `satisfies` for const objects with inferred types
